newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Nov 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Nov 4.

text.p: British fund management group Invesco has agreed to buy AIM Management Group Inc of the United States for $1.6 billion, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.
Other top stories included:
- CSX Corp is holding talks with Norfolk Southern Corp about a possible sale of some material assets after its proposed merger with Conrail Inc.
- Sierra Health Services Inc has signed an agreement worth $509 million to merge with Physician Corp of America .
- Sequent Computer Systems Inc is to introduce on Monday a new computer based on NUMA, an approach that allows computers to work faster and stronger.
- Federal-Mogul Corp is expected to appoint Richard Snell as its chairman and chief executive officer on Monday.
- Merck & Co Inc will delay expanded distribution of its new AIDS drug until next year.
- Dayton Hudson Corp cut 7.2 percent of its staff at its department store unit.
- British Telecommunications Plc agreed to buy the 80 percent of MCI Communications Corp that it did not already own for $20.8 billion in cash and stock.
- J.C. Penney Co Inc agreed to buy Eckerd Corp for $2.5 billion in cash and stock plus assumed debt.
- General Motors Corp and the United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative labor agreement.
- Carter-Wallace Inc rejected an offer from a financier to buy it for $835 million.
- Boeing Co is developing devices for its 737 jetliners to protect against possibly dangerous rudder movements.
- Federated Department Stores Inc plans a Macy's catalog for the new year.
- Viacom Inc's quarterly profit were higher than expected.
- The U.S. Federal Reserve will not likely change interest rates when its policy makers meet November 13.
- Corporate profit grew in the third quarter despite slower economic growth.
- Friday's economic data showed that growth began to slow down this fall.
- Bond investors foresee the 30-year, bellwether Treasury bond trading at rates between 6.60 percent and 6.75 percent compared to 6.75 percent and 7.25 percent in recent months.

- One Wall Street analyst says Sears Roebuck reported growing earnigs this year due to a 1993 balance-sheet maneuver that softened the impact of soaring levels of bad credit card debt among its card holders.
-- New York Newsdesk 212 859-1610
